title: Cornell Assessment of Pediatric Delirium (CAPD)
description: Screens for delirium in pediatric patients through behavioral assessment of awareness, cognition, and psychomotor symptoms.

parameters.name: underactive
parameters.description: Underactive - very little movement while awake (0=Never, 1=Rarely, 2=Sometimes, 3=Often, 4=Always)

parameters.name: slow_response
parameters.description: Takes long time to respond to interactions (0=Never, 1=Rarely, 2=Sometimes, 3=Often, 4=Always)

parameters.name: patient_age
parameters.description: Patient age in years (used for developmental context)

result.name: capd_assessment
result.description: CAPD delirium screening results with clinical recommendations

ranges.interpretation: Patient does not meet criteria for delirium. Continue routine monitoring and reassess regularly.
Patient meets criteria for pediatric delirium. Investigate underlying causes and implement management strategies.

references: Traube C, Silver G, Kearney J, Patel A, Atkinson TM, Yoon MJ, et al. Cornell Assessment of Pediatric Delirium: a valid, rapid, observational tool for screening delirium in the PICU. Crit Care Med. 2014 Mar;42(3):656-63. doi: 10.1097/CCM.0b013e3182a66b76.

Silver G, Traube C, Gerber LM, Sun X, Kearney J, Patel A, et al. Pediatric delirium and associated risk factors: a single-center prospective observational study. Pediatr Crit Care Med. 2015 May;16(4):303-9. doi: 10.1097/PCC.0000000000000356.

Traube C, Silver G, Gerber LM, Kaur S, Mauer EA, Kerson A, et al. Delirium and mortality in critically ill children: epidemiology and outcomes of pediatric delirium. Crit Care Med. 2017 May;45(5):891-898. doi: 10.1097/CCM.0000000000002324.

Smith HA, Boyd J, Fuchs DC, Melvin K, Berry P, Shintani A, et al. Diagnosing delirium in critically ill children: Validity and reliability of the Pediatric Confusion Assessment Method for the Intensive Care Unit. Crit Care Med. 2011 Jan;39(1):150-7. doi: 10.1097/CCM.0b013e3181feb489.
formula: Sum of all 8 domain scores (0-32 points). CAPD positive if total score ≥ 9 points
notes: The CAPD is a validated tool for detecting delirium in pediatric patients aged 0-21 years
Based on behavioral observations during routine nursing care - no patient participation required
Can be completed in less than 2 minutes by bedside nurses
Applicable to both developmentally normal and delayed children
Sensitivity 94.1% and specificity varies by age group (highest in younger children)
Should be performed every nursing shift for all pediatric ICU patients
Cutoff score ≥9 optimizes sensitivity for delirium detection
Developmental anchor points help guide age-appropriate assessment
Delirium prevalence in pediatric ICU patients is approximately 20-25%
Early detection allows for prompt intervention and improved outcomes
Part of comprehensive pediatric delirium screening and management protocols
